{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3150411,"name":"Erdem Tellioglu","username":"Erdemtel1","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/erdemtel1/{size}/188063_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-22T08:57:47.652Z","cooked":"

In our robot, specifically in the elevator system, we used 1/2 in hex bearings and gears. However, we couldn’t find the compatible hex shaft ( which is 1/2 in hex ) in our country to use in our system. That’s why we decided to use 12mm hex shaft. When compared with 1/2 in hex which is 12.7mm in milimeters, there is a 0.7 mm difference between these two shafts. Do you think that will cause problems in our elevator system ?

This can depend on what you are going to use. For example if you are using a 1/2” hex bored things that won’t be compatible. Other than that you can made custom parts to insert materials compatible with 12mm hex bored things.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2023-02-22T09:14:02.287Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":207,"readers_count":206,"score":46.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":427694,"topic_slug":"using-12mm-hex-shaft-instead-of-1-2-inch-12-7mm-hex-shaft","display_username":"Gökalp","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":47031,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/using-12mm-hex-shaft-instead-of-1-2-inch-12-7mm-hex-shaft/427694/3","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3150423,"name":"EricH","username":"EricH","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/erich/{size}/128938_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-22T09:23:38.971Z","cooked":"

I don’t think you’ll have issues. I KNOW you’ll have issues, maybe not right away but eventually, say about the time you hit playoffs.

Specifically, slop. Your shaft will be sloppy in every single bearing and gear. And I mean that literally.

“But Eric, why is slop bad?” It tends to wear things out. You could lose tension in chains really easily. Your hex holes are going to try to round themselves, if the shaft doesn’t beat them to it. How about gears sliding out of alignment without you doing anything? (I could list off a few more possible issues.) (Also, for the Americans: .027" difference in size.)

That said, it’s a relatively easy fix, because the shaft is smaller than the hexes in the bearings. Figure out your local place that sells shim stock, and get .35mm thickness, maybe .3mm will be “close enough”. (For the Americans here: .013" down to .011.) You want one piece per side in every place the 12mm shaft goes through a bearing, gear, sprocket… (I will say that you may be able to use 1 piece and wrap around all 6 sides in some cases… no guarantees.) It’s going to be a long and tedious job, don’t get me wrong. But it’s going to save you a lot of worn-out parts. And, for next season… maybe you’ll be able to stock up on 1/2" hex in the offseason, somehow… (There’s also theoretically an option to oversize hex shaft and machine down. I would NOT suggest this unless you’ve got pretty advanced machining capability.)

I’ll add in one other alternative. If you have a lathe, you could turn down the ends of the shaft and use normal round bearings instead of hex bearings. That will let you get a good fit without any slop in those, and it might be quicker than trying to shim them. You would still want to shim the gears, though! I agree with Eric - you will have a problem if you don’t address the slop!

If .5" keyed round stock is available, you can use that as well. Assuming you have a 1/8" broach you can broach a keyway in the flat part of the hex for those things that the shaft needs to drive. For the 1/2" hex bearings the round shaft will run in those just fine.

This highlights one of the things I don’t like FRC offerings. 1/2" hex is not standard in industry because of the difficulties of working with it. Tooling is more expensive for it. You also have to worry about having it clocked right if that is important to the design. Limited number of vendors that offer a 1/2" hex option.

Round stock is far easier from many more vendors. You can easily cut a keyway into the round stock if you can’t get the keyed round stock. A 1/2" reamer and broach can quickly get you a pulley, sprocket or gear ready to use if you can’t already purchase it that way or the size you want.
